text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
MATERIAL CHANGES
) Incorporated the provisions of the October
, Internal Guidance Memo (IGM) TE/GE-
with the subject line Single Type of Examination issued by the Acting Director, Employee Plans into IRM section
and IRM

The IGM was effective the date it was issued and provides that examinations are no longer classiﬁed as either Field or OCE. The IGM’s result is a single type of examination. The examination’s location is determined by the agent and front-line manager on a case by case basis. (
) Enhanced IRM
, Program, Scope and Objectives, and the subsections thereunder, and added new section IRM
, Program Controls, to provide more information on the internal controls regulating EP Examinations. Reorganized material for improved readability and uniformity with other EP, Examination IRMs. (
) Changed name of IRM
from Acronyms and Forms to Acronyms, Abbreviations, Forms and Pubs and updated table names reﬂect the applicable contents. (
) Fax numbers were eliminated throughout the document because of the removal of fax machines. (
) Made editorial changes, including changes for Plain Language (the Plain Writing Act of
), throughout the document.

Incorporated the provisions of the October 5, 2018, Internal Guidance Memo (IGM) TE/GE-04-1018- 0024 with the subject line Single Type of Examination issued by the Acting Director, Employee Plans into IRM section 4.71.21.1.2 and IRM 4.71.21.4.1. The IGM was effective the date it was issued and provides that examinations are no longer classiﬁed as either Field or OCE. The IGM’s result is a single type of examination. The examination’s location is determined by the agent and the front-line manager on a case by case basis.

Enhanced IRM 4.71.21, 1, Program, Scope and Objectives, and the subsections thereunder, and added new section IRM 4.71.21.1.3, Program Controls, to provide more information on the internal controls regulating EP Examinations. Reorganized material for improved readability and uniformity with other EP, Examination IRMs.
Changed name of IRM 4.71.21.1.4 from Acronyms and Forms to Acronyms, Abbreviations, Forms and Pubs and updated table names reﬂect the applicable contents.
Fax numbers were eliminated throughout the document because of the removal of fax machines.

) There are ﬁve major U.S. territories: • American Samoa • Guam • Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands (CNMI) • Puerto Rico • U.S. Virgin Islands (USVI) (

) U.S. statutory laws generally apply to the U.S. territories. Generally, U.S. territory residents are full U.S. citizens. However, for tax purposes the IRC treats the U.S. territories as foreign countries. a. When the IRC uses the term in a geographical sense, the “United (U.S.) includes only the

states and the District of Columbia. b. Income derived from the U.S. territories is ordinarily treated as foreign source income and entities organized in the territories are generally treated as foreign persons. (

) This IRM is a general overview of how to conduct an audit of qualiﬁed retire- ment plans in Puerto Rico and the USVI. a. The audit techniques and audit scope depend on the type of plan and jurisdiction of the plan. b. The agent and manager determine the examination’s location for each case. c. Examinations may be assigned to you as part of the general program or from compliance checks. See IRM
, Case Selection Criteria and IRM
, Compliance Checks. Note: In the future, we’ll revise the IRM to include procedures to address the U.S. territories.
Employee Plans Examination of Returns

Use professional judgement according to auditing standards to make ﬁndings of fact and apply the IRS’s position on issues of law to determine the correct tax liability. Exercise this authority to obtain the greatest number of tax determination agreements without sacriﬁcing the quality or integrity of those determina- tions and to dispose of tax differences at the lowest level. See IRM
, Servicewide Policies and Authorities, Policy Statements for the Examining Process.
All examinations are conducted according to Policy Statement 1-236, Fairness and Integrity in Enforcement Selection. See IRM 1.2.10.37, Policy Statement

Note: In the future, we’ll revise the IRM to include procedures to address the other U.S. territories.

)(B)(ii)) to the U.S. or another foreign country. Competent Authority: a tax treaty requires the designation of a Authority for each country that is a party to the treaty. a. The respective Competent Authorities administer the provisions of the treaty. b. The Commissioner, LB&I acts as the U.S. Competent Authority to ister the operating provisions of tax treaties and interpret and applying these treaties. c. In interpreting and applying treaties, the Commissioner, LB&I acts with the concurrence of the Associate Chief Counsel (International). Delegation Order
(Rev.

Control Test: one or more U.S. persons must have the authority to control substantial trust decisions. U.S. persons include: • A citizen or resident of the U.S • A domestic partnership • A domestic corporation • Any estate (other than a foreign estate) • A domestic trust Court Test: a U.S. court must be able to exercise primary supervision over trust’s administration. Only a court within the geographical U.S. is court within the U.S. Domestic Corporation: a domestic corporation is a corporation that its affairs in its home country. a. A company that conducts business in a different country from the one which it was created is called a foreign corporation. b. For federal tax purposes, the IRS considers a corporation founded in state or applicable U.S. territory and subject to that state or territory’s laws to be a domestic corporation. Example: A company both founded in and operating out of Florida Puerto Rico is considered a U.S. domestic corporation. Example: A company founded in Canada is considered a foreign company in the U.S.
Competent Authority: a tax treaty requires the designation of a Competent Authority for each country that is a party to the treaty.

The respective Competent Authorities administer the provisions of the treaty. The Commissioner, LB&I acts as the U.S. Competent Authority to admin- ister the operating provisions of tax treaties and interpret and applying these treaties. In interpreting and applying treaties, the Commissioner, LB&I acts only with the concurrence of the Associate Chief Counsel (International). See Delegation Order
(Rev.
). See also IRM
, Delegation Order

A company that conducts business in a different country from the one in which it was created is called a foreign corporation. For federal tax purposes, the IRS considers a corporation founded in any state or applicable U.S. territory and subject to that state or territory’s laws to be a domestic corporation.
Example: A company both founded in and operating out of Florida and Puerto Rico is considered a U.S. domestic corporation.
Example: A company founded in Canada is considered a foreign company in the U.S.
Example: However, a subsidiary of a foreign company that was incorpo- rated in the U.S. may be classiﬁed as a domestic corporation.
) Dual Qualiﬁed Plan: a U.S. sponsor’s plan with a trust in the U.S., may operate in Puerto Rico and cover Puerto Rico employees. The Dual Qualiﬁed Plan must satisfy both the requirements of IRC
(a) and Puerto Rico Code (PRC) section
(a). The sponsor of a dual qualiﬁed plan may request under the IRS’ determination letter program a plan document review for compliance with applicable rules under IRC

Dual Qualiﬁed Plan: a U.S. sponsor’s plan with a trust in the U.S., may operate in Puerto Rico and cover Puerto Rico employees. The Dual Qualiﬁed Plan must satisfy both the requirements of IRC 401(a) and Puerto Rico Code (PRC) section 1165(a). The sponsor of a dual qualiﬁed plan may request the IRS’ determination letter program a plan document review for compliance with applicable rules under IRC 401(a).

for Plans in U.S. Territories

) Mirror Code System of Taxation. The territory adopts the IRC as if it the territory’s code, except that the name of the territory is substituted for U.S. and vice versa. The territories that use a Mirror Code System of are the USVI, Guam and CNMI. (
) Plan Sponsor. A designated party, usually a company or employer, that lishes a retirement plan, such as an IRC
(k) plan established for the of the organization’s employees. (

) Residual Tax Liability: generally, Bona Fide Residents of the USVI don’t to ﬁle with the U.S. for any tax year in which they are a Bona Fide during the entire tax year, if they: a. Report and pay tax on their income from all sources to the USVI. b. Identify the source(s) of the income on the return. (
) Section

: most residents of Puerto Rico are U.S. citizens, but aren’t subject to U.S. federal income tax, except on income from non-Puerto sources. Note: They may exclude salary earned from non-Puerto Rico sources deferred under a
(k)-type plan, subject to limitations, as long as the plan is qualiﬁed by the Puerto Rico tax authorities (the Hacienda). (

) Tax Coordination Agreement. Tax treaties or agreements allowing the Competent Authorities of the U.S. and the tax department of the relevant territory to: a. Exchange information b. Provide mutual assistance to prevent the evasion of tax and tax c. Provide mutual assistance and training d. Improve tax administration procedures (
) Trust Situs. The location where the trustee performs his or her duties of managing the trust. (
) U.S. Citizen. Under the Fourteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution, term U.S. Citizen includes: • A person born in the U.S. or a possession • A naturalized citizen (
) U.S. Source Income. U.S. Source Income generally includes income tively connected with either: • A trade or business in the U.S. • Passive U.S. Source Income. (
) United States Virgin Islands Bureau of Internal Revenue (BIR). BIR is Virgin Islands Department of Treasury which oversees the administration tax laws in the U.S. Virgin Islands. (
) Worldwide Source Income. U.S. Citizens and resident aliens must report income from all sources within and outside of the U.S.

) Mirror Code System of Taxation. The territory adopts the IRC as if it were the territory’s code, except that the name of the territory is substituted for the U.S. and vice versa. The territories that use a Mirror Code System of Taxation are the USVI, Guam and CNMI. (
) Plan Sponsor. A designated party, usually a company or employer, that lishes a retirement plan, such as an IRC
(k) plan established for the of the organization’s employees. (

) Residual Tax Liability: generally, Bona Fide Residents of the USVI don’t to ﬁle with the U.S. for any tax year in which they are a Bona Fide Resident during the entire tax year, if they: a. Report and pay tax on their income from all sources to the USVI. b. Identify the source(s) of the income on the return. (
) Section

: most residents of Puerto Rico are U.S. citizens, but aren’t subject to U.S. federal income tax, except on income from non-Puerto Rico sources. Note: They may exclude salary earned from non-Puerto Rico sources deferred under a
(k)-type plan, subject to limitations, as long as the plan is qualiﬁed by the Puerto Rico tax authorities (the Hacienda).
Section 933: most residents of Puerto Rico are U.S. citizens, but aren’t subject to U.S. federal income tax, except on income from non-Puerto
Worldwide Source Income. U.S. Citizens and resident aliens must report income from all sources within and outside of the U.S.
Employee Plans Examination of Returns

Employee Plans Examination of a. For a U.S. Citizen or resident alien, the rules for ﬁling income, estate gift tax returns and for paying estimated tax are generally the same whether they are living in the U.S. or abroad. b. The Puerto Rican government taxes Puerto Rico residents on their worldwide income. Puerto Rico is part of the U.S. and most U.S. laws apply in Puerto Rico. c. However, for Puerto Rico residents: • Puerto Rico source income is generally exempt from U.S. indi- vidual income tax. • Income from sources outside Puerto Rico is subject to U.S. taxation. (

) Treatment of U.S. Territories under Title I of ERISA. For purposes of Title I, the term United States includes the U.S. territories. Even though the IRC doesn’t apply within the U.S. territories, the following ERISA Title
re- quirements do: • Minimum participation • Vesting and funding rules • Form
ﬁling obligations Note: This means the plans maintained in the territories are subject to DOL juris- diction. (

) Territory Tax System and Relationship to the U.S. Tax Code. The U.S. tories of American Samoa, Guam, the CNMI, Puerto Rico, and the USVI are generally treated as foreign for U.S. tax purposes, unless otherwise speciﬁed in the Code or related statutes. a. Each U.S. territory has a semi-autonomous territorial income tax it administers. b. Each of the territories’ tax systems imposes income tax upon (including U.S. citizens and residents) who are Bona Fide Residents of the territory or who have income from sources within the territory. c. Various Code sections generally allow Bona Fide Residents to exclude territory source income from federal gross income. These Bona Fide Residents generally ﬁle income tax returns with their U.S. territory authority and, depending on the speciﬁc territory or source of income, may be exempted from having to ﬁle a federal income tax return with IRS. d. The territories of Guam, CNMI and the USVI have a Mirror Code of Taxation to the U.S. By contrast, the U.S. territories of Puerto Rico American Samoa have income tax laws that are similar to U.S. income tax laws, but that aren’t necessarily mirrored or directly linked to the Code. (

) Tax Coordination Agreements and Mutual Agreement Procedures. The IRS has entered Tax Coordination Agreements with each of the ﬁve major territories allowing the IRS and the ﬁve territorial tax departments to do the tivities in IRM
Puerto Rico source income is generally exempt from U.S. vidual income tax. Income from sources outside Puerto Rico is subject to U.S. taxation.

Treatment of U.S. Territories under Title I of ERISA. For purposes of ERISA Title I, the term United States includes the U.S. territories. Even though the IRC doesn’t apply within the U.S. territories, the following ERISA Title
re- quirements do:
4.71.21.3 (07-15-2019) Introduction to Retirement Plans Maintained in U.S. Territories

diction. Territory Tax System and Relationship to the U.S. Tax Code. The U.S. tories of American Samoa, Guam, the CNMI, Puerto Rico, and the USVI are generally treated as foreign for U.S. tax purposes, unless otherwise speciﬁed in the Code or related statutes. a. Each U.S. territory has a semi-autonomous territorial income tax system it administers. b. Each of the territories’ tax systems imposes income tax upon individuals (including U.S. citizens and residents) who are Bona Fide Residents of the territory or who have income from sources within the territory. c. Various Code sections generally allow Bona Fide Residents to exclude territory source income from federal gross income. These Bona Fide Residents generally ﬁle income tax returns with their U.S. territory taxing authority and, depending on the speciﬁc territory or source of income, may be exempted from having to ﬁle a federal income tax return with the IRS. d. The territories of Guam, CNMI and the USVI have a Mirror Code Section of Taxation to the U.S. By contrast, the U.S. territories of Puerto Rico American Samoa have income tax laws that are similar to U.S. income tax laws, but that aren’t necessarily mirrored or directly linked to the Code. Tax Coordination Agreements and Mutual Agreement Procedures. The IRS has entered Tax Coordination Agreements with each of the ﬁve major U.S. territories allowing the IRS and the ﬁve territorial tax departments to do the ac- tivities in IRM
Territory Tax System and Relationship to the U.S. Tax Code. The U.S. terri
tories of American Samoa, Guam, the CNMI, Puerto Rico, and the USVI are generally treated as foreign for U.S. tax purposes, unless otherwise speciﬁed in the Code or related statutes.
Procedures for Plans in U.S. Territories 4.71.21 page

Tax Coordination Agreements allow the U.S. Competent Authorities and the relevant territory to resolve, by mutual agreement, inconsistent tax treatment between the two jurisdictions. Mutual Agreement Procedures exist to settle issues where there is sistent tax treatment between the IRS and the U.S. territories’ taxing authorities. These issues usually involve allocations of income, deduc
tions, credits, or allowances between related persons, determinations of residency, and determinations of the source of income and related expenses.
Retirement plans adopted by employers in Puerto Rico are generally similar to qualiﬁed plans adopted by employers in the U.S. (e.g., deﬁned beneﬁt, stock bonus, and proﬁt sharing plans).
There are three types of retirement plans covering residents of Puerto that provide tax-favored beneﬁts under U.S. law:

Plan Type Plan Characteristics 1.) Puerto Rico plans qualiﬁed in Puerto Rico only a. If a Puerto Rico pension plan with a trust (ERISA section 1022(i)(1)) sited in Puerto Rico (or the U.S.) is exempt under PRC section 1081.01, and all the par- ticipants are residents of Puerto Rico, the trust is treated as exempt under IRC 501(a) as though it were part of a qualiﬁed plan under IRC 401(a). The effect of ERISA section 1022(i)(1) is to exclude a Puerto Rico trust’s income earned in the U.S., from U.S. taxation even though the plan is not qualiﬁed under IRC 401(a). b. Participants in, and employers maintaining, an ERISA section 1022(i)(1) plan aren’t generally eligible for favorable tax treatment under IRC 402 (re: the taxability of a beneﬁ- ciary of an employees’ trust) or IRC 404 (re: deductions for contributions of an employer to an employees’ trust). c. Although these plans aren’t subject to IRC 401(a), they are subject to ERISA Title I. Compliance with Title I of ERISA is a qualiﬁ- cation requirement under PRC section 1081.01(a)(9). d. Although these plans aren’t subject to the funding standards in IRC 412, IRC 430, and IRC 431, funding standards are imposed on these plans under similar provisions in ERISA Title 1. e. These plans would normally not be subject to IRS examination. However, sometimes a plan may have intended to be an ERISA section 1022(i)(1) plan, but due to a plan sponsor or administrator’s action, the plan would have to qualify under IRC 401

), a Puerto Rico sponsor may make a prospective and irrevo- election for the plan to comply with all of the qualiﬁcation provisions, except for the Trust requirement. The election: Enables the plan to cover both U.S. and Puerto Rican employees. Once made, is irrevocable and can’t be changed. Therefore, the plan must continue to qualify until it’s terminated and all assets have been distributed. Requires the plan to meet all IRC
(a) re- quirements (other than the requirement that the trust be sited in the United States) at all times. The sponsoring employer can claim a deduction under the rules of IRC

Procedures for Plans in U.S. Territories 4.71.21
Plan Characteristics a. U.S. based employer with the trust situs in the U.S. covering Puerto Rican employees. b. Must satisfy both the requirements of IRC
(a) and PRC section
(a). c. Sponsor may have its plan document reviewed for compliance with IRC
(a) under the IRS’s determination letter program. The standard of review is the same as for any other plan submitted with the intent to be determined to be qualiﬁed under IRC

(a). Note: An EP Determination specialist may make a referral to EP Exam for opera- tional defects found during the determination letter process. d. Because the trust of Dual Qualiﬁed Plan is sited in the U.S., it’s exempt from taxation under IRC
(a) as long as the related plan satisﬁes the qualiﬁcation requirements of IRC
(a), similar to any other qualiﬁed plan/ trust. However, if the plan is required to satisfy any PRC requirements that contradict the requirements of IRC
(a), its qualiﬁed status under the Code might be jeopardized. Note: This is most likely to happen with an IRC
(k) plan, due to different deﬁ- nitions of a highly compensated employee (HCE under IRC

(q)), different methods for determining excluded employees under coverage testing, different dollar amounts that can be deferred, and different correc- tion methods for failing the actual deferral percentage (ADP under IRC
)(A)) test. e. Employers sponsoring these plans may claim deductions for plan contributions to the extent allowed under IRC
f. Subject to examination by EP Exam.

, as of a Memorandum of Understanding entered between the IRS, TEGE USVI Bureau of Internal Revenue (BIR). Employers in the USVI generally adopt retirement plans similar to those adopted by U.S. employers (such as deﬁned beneﬁt, stock bonus, and sharing plans). IRC

(k) plans are the most common. The IRS has concurrent jurisdiction with the BIR over USVI plans a. The potential for a USVI trust to earn FDAP income on U.S. b. Individuals potentially owing residual taxes to the U.S. if a USVI no longer qualiﬁed under the USVI Code,

Procedures for Plans in U.S. Territories 4.71.21 page
Note: Furthermore, because USVI plans are covered under ERISA Title I, they fall within the audit jurisdiction of the U.S. Department of Labor. (

) USVI plan sponsors may submit requests for determination letters to IRS Rulings and Agreements (R&A) in Cincinnati using the same procedures apply to U.S. plan sponsors. a. EP R&A issues determination letters on whether a plan is qualiﬁed the U.S. IRC. b. EP R&A doesn’t rule on qualiﬁcation under the USVI Mirror Code of Taxation; however, the USVI BIR may recognize the determination letter for qualiﬁcation under the USVI Mirror Code System of Taxation. (
) The number of USVI plans that have received a favorable determination is relatively small (less than
). Remember that all USVI plans (whether not they have a favorable determination letter) come under the IRS’s tion, as well as that of the BIR. (

) BIR agents conduct most of the audits of USVI plans. a. EP rarely audits USVI plans (for examples include referrals, additional training initiatives, special projects, etc.) b. The BIR refers issues they ﬁnd on audits to IRS EP and vice versa. (

) Generally, any income tax adjustments and closing agreement sanctions payable to the BIR, as opposed to the IRS. Note: When IRS collects income taxes and/or closing agreement sanctions collected by IRS, whether conducted unilaterally or jointly with a BIR we turn them over to the BIR. (
) If you discover a funding deﬁciency, the plan sponsor must correct it. neither the IRS nor the BIR is entitled to collect excise taxes under IRC See IRM
, Income and Excise Tax Related to USVI Plans, for an explanation. (
) Follow the procedures in IRM
, Pre-audit Analysis, with one requirement. Your group manager contacts the BIR as a courtesy to allow them the opportunity to assign a trained agent to conduct the audit jointly. (
) Request the same records you’d request for the same type of plan by a domestic plan sponsor. (
) Use the same interview questions as those for the same plan type by a domestic plan sponsor. (
) Auditing techniques and audit scope depend on the type of audit. Approach both the same as you would for a plan maintained by a domestic plan (

) Income from the USVI is subject to taxation under a Mirror Income Tax of Taxation (Mirror Code). Under the Mirror Code, the USVI adopts the U.S. IRC as if it were the territory’s code, except that the name of the territory is substituted for the U. S., and vice versa. So, plans under the USVI Mirror Code mirror the IRC’s: Internal Revenue Manual
Note: Furthermore, because USVI plans are covered under ERISA Title I, they also fall within the audit jurisdiction of the U.S. Department of Labor.
Auditing techniques and audit scope depend on the type of audit. Approach both the same as you would for a plan maintained by a domestic plan

Income from the USVI is subject to taxation under a Mirror Income Tax System of Taxation (Mirror Code). Under the Mirror Code, the USVI adopts the U.S. IRC as if it were the territory’s code, except that the name of the territory is substituted for the U. S., and vice versa. So, plans under the USVI Mirror Code mirror the IRC’s:
Employee Plans Examination of Returns

a. Income tax requirements b. Procedural rules c. Regulations and other interpretations of the USVI Code. Exception: Other parts of the IRC, including the estate and gift tax rules and excise taxes, aren’t mirrored. (

) In general, U.S. citizens and residents pay tax to the U.S. on their income, regardless of where they reside or where the income is sourced. However, if you’re a Bona Fide Resident of the USVI, you ﬁle your return and pay any tax due to the USVI. (

) U.S. citizens and U.S. residents who are Bona Fide Residents of the USVI don’t owe income tax to the U.S. and aren’t subject to IRS reporting ments (except for any residual tax described below). So, it’s important to determine whether an individual is a Bona Fide Resident to calculate tax liability. (
) A Bona Fide Resident of the USVI, under IRC
(a), is generally a person who meets all of these criteria: a. Is present in the USVI for at least
days during the taxable year b. Doesn’t have a tax home (per IRC
)) outside the USVI during taxable year c. Doesn’t have a closer connection (per IRC
)(B)(ii)) to the or a foreign country than to the USVI. Note: Taxpayers who change their residency status to or from the USVI have reporting requirement with the IRS (IRC
(c)). They use Form
for this purpose. (
) A taxpayer is required to ﬁle identical income tax returns with both the U.S. and the USVI per IRC

(b) if he/she is either a U.S. citizen or resident not a Bona Fide Resident of the USVI and has: a. USVI source income b. Income effectively connected with the conduct of a trade or business the USVI (
) Taxpayers required to ﬁle in IRM
) above must: a. Submit Form
, along with the tax return when they ﬁle. b. Pay any tax due to the USVI (only). However, that tax is allowed as a credit against the individual’s U.S. tax liability. (
) The effect of IRC

(c) is that Bona Fide Residents of the USVI report worldwide income to the BIR and don’t owe tax to the U.S. even on U.S. Source Income. a. However, ﬁlers who don’t report all of their income and the income source to the BIR lose their status as Bona Fide Residents of the under IRC
(c) and must: • File with both the BIR and the IRS as IRC
(a) ﬁlers • Submit a Form
and Form
to the IRS on their U.S. Source Income. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) A corporation created or organized in the USVI is considered a foreign ration and is required to ﬁle Form

-F for FDAP income from sources the U.S. and income that is effectively connected with the conduct of a business in the U.S. a. A USVI corporation doing business in the U.S. must ﬁle a return with: • The IRS to report its income from U.S. sources • The USVI to report its worldwide income and is permitted a foreign tax credit for tax paid to the IRS b. Likewise, a U.S. corporation doing business in the USVI must ﬁle a return with: • The BIR to pay tax on income from sources in the USVI; • The IRS to pay tax on its worldwide income, and is permitted to take a foreign tax credit for the tax paid to the USVI.
